comments.commentBody: I think this is absolutely correct, there obviously exists a large dichotomy in the likely hood to invest, or the marginal propensity to consume, between Walmart shoppers and Goldman Sachs spokes(wo)men.
This is quite kewl.  I have HALloween and now Leapy has LEAPy day.  The rest of you? Eat your hearts out ... ha ha ha ha ha.
glenn - Bingo !

The author, Katalan Balog, writes, "Much of Kierkegaard’s philosophy is a warning against the tendency...to take an increasingly objective, abstract perspective on the world. While the paradigm example of this is science, it is most problematic when applied to one’s own life and existence."

I am inclined to disagree as to what constitutes the most problematic implication of increased "objectivity." Balog appears to juxtapose the extremes of universal truths -- science -- with individual perception and experience. This seems much too limited a view of the real world. "Objectivity" is only knowable through the subjectivity of the individual. At the same time, "subjectivity" is governed by universal truths, whether we are aware of them or not.

I would think that what is most problematic is not increased "objectivity" but, rather, the confusion of "objectivity" and "subjectivity" or, perhaps, the cloaking of subjectivity in the mantle of objectivity. It has become common to to take claims of hope, fear, belief, and faith and state them as facts, as objective truths. We see this not merely in the current political environment but also in everyday life in such "controversies" as vaccines and anthropogenic global warming.

In a previous age, science had to be cloaked in faith. By contrast, in our current age, faith seemingly needs to be cloaked in science.

Agree with everything in your post, but (my apologies for being a pendant): the notion of the world-as-will-and-presentation was Schopenhauer's, not Nietzsche's. Although, of course, the latter stole this one from the former, as he did with so many things.

If Marx was Hegel stood on his head, Nietzsche was Schopenhauer turned inside out.

I agree there's both subjectivity & objectivity in every human life. But at the end it is exactly like that: it's life, which in a Gestalt viewpoint means it goes beyond subject & object. Life, as long as it's human, is more related to Nietzsche' wille und vorstellung through insight, so that we shouldn't forget that science & 'objectivity' are just words to define a method to make world understandable in the most inner space of our mind, so we can afford to deal with nature & survive as individuals first, as species then. Kierkegaard' work is pointing out to give value to our lives (all lives matter), allowing us to recognize virtue from sin, and that's always done through language, language creates reality ('objective' outer world), as it all started one million years B.P. in the way of myth, to help us to understand for surviving, it is an intrinsic (genetic maybe?) property of mankind to get an agreement, a social consensus, on behalf of each individual' goal: autopoiesis (to reproduce him/herself).

We are speaking on behalf of the millions of people, worldwide, who suffer lifetime's filled with constant ‘vertigo’ from a little known and very misunderstood disease, known as Meniere's disease.

Meniere’s disease steals lives, leaving those unable to function as they once did. Many sufferers are reduced to bystanders to their own existence, unable to work, drive, attend family gatherings, or simply play with their kids. Meniere’s causes dizziness, severe vertigo, tinnitus, sensitivity to light and sounds and other normal everyday activities. Meniere’s attacks leave their victims so dizzy and unable to walk or balance, with even the slightest movement bringing hours of nausea and vomiting. If that wasn’t enough, most Meniere’s sufferers develop hearing loss and many go completely deaf.

Additionally, in a 2009 study on post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) performed by Kirby, S.E. and Yardley, L. it was found that the incidence of (PTSD) and health anxiety is much higher than in non-sufferers. Nearly one in eight people with Ménière’s were found to meet the criteria for full PTSD, compared to the general population where just one in sixty has PTSD. Yet, Meniere’s remains relatively unknown worldwide and dramatically underfunded when it comes to crucial research dollars.

Please help by signing our petition for U2 Meniere's Awareness:

https://www.change.org/p/bono-and-u2-meniere-s-disease-raise-awareness
The U.S. government will always step in to keep the wealthy from becoming non-wealthy. This is the way it has been for the last 50 years. Why would someone even question the notion.

The vertigo I experienced was a diagnosed by my doctor, a neuro otologist. He did a quick exam and told me what it was and sent me off to a Physical Therapist that specializes in treatment of BPPV. The PT laid me on a table and moved my head in a few specific ways more or less rolling it a bit very gently and within 10 minutes I felt amazing.  I think she referred to it as an Epley maneuver. This was maybe 10 years ago and I've never had a reoccurrence of the vertigo. BTW I am a long ago sufferer of Menieres Disease which the same doctor "cured" me of with injections of gentamiacin. I suffered from Menieres off and on for 25 years and those shots virtually took the symptoms away. I am a blessed man
Ok, I will. Thank you!

I was diagnosed with BPPV and got some relief with these maneuvers.  The symptoms persisted, though were much milder, but turned out to be related to a brain tumor.  I suggest that anyone who doesn't get complete and permanent relief discuss this possibility with their MD.

I suffer from this, and am 46.  I developed this after a car accident 10 years ago; I'd wake from sleep and grab the bed, certain that it was spinning fast enough to throw me against the wall.  Doctors suggested drugs, and never mentioned this as a potential solution.  Every emergency room doctor needs to be trained in this procedure - it changes lives.  I suffered for 6 months before I found out about the Epley maneuver on my own, and immediately knew it was working as I performed the movements.  Thanks, internet!
Its great to see an article about a simple, free and effective way to treat an ailment. Can you write another one, about the Friggy flip?

"But don't do Epley or 1/2 somersault until BPPV has been diagnosed by a physician,"

Why not? What harm, other than possibly depriving a will be done by trying this? Depriving a physician of a fee?

Thank you.  I was misdiagnosed with BPPV (!) after a battery of tests all came back negative, but the doctor insisted that I had vertigo.  Turns out migraine aura was what I was actually experiencing (very similar symptoms.)  Some great drugs and an even better neurologist has me straightened out.  Haven't had the same symptoms in YEARS.

I don't understand. If the Epley maneuver or similar relieves the symptoms, and the symptoms don't recur, doesn't that indicate that the problem is solved, or manageable?

Does it make any sense that a tumor or MS could induce vertigo and that the Epley maneuver could stop the vertigo.

While we ER physicians use the Epley maneuver often, my experience is that it works far less than 90% of the time reported in the literature; I've asked my colleagues and I'm not alone. It's also important that dangerous causes of vertigo be ruled out. This can only be done by a trained physician and is no easy task. Many strokes are missed, as the article mentions. But vertigo can be caused by "central" causes like tumors or MS. Even diabetic crises can cause vertigo. So, please see a doctor. Sometimes imaging will be necessary, and sometimes not. But don't do Epley or 1/2 somersault until BPPV has been diagnosed by a physician. Thanks everyone.

Never was taught this in medical school.  Heard about it from a non-physician friend about 15 years ago, who had been lucky to have a doctor who referred her to PT for the Epley maneuver when she had sudden onset of vertigo.  Years later, I used it on my spouse when he awoke with sudden severe vertigo.  It worked immediately.  You can find numerous videos on youtube showing the procedure.  Ever since I found out about it, it's my first step in a workup of vertigo, before any other treatments or tests, since it's harmless, and only costs an additional ten minutes of office time.

I dream with the day when shark fishing is banned worldwide.

The destruction of the species, is not worth some one's tacos, or some one's soup.

Cool is as cool does. I remember a market segment test that classified as Bohemian Middle Class. Not spending on what the marketers considered normal for my earning level. Cool. In high school there were those that avoided sports and focused on cars or motorcycles and were called Cool.
Cool was isolated from "safe" groups but purposeful in their look and dress and passions. We nerds did not fit with the jocks nor the "cool ones" but we survived and always longed to be "cool" but never to be "jocks." Cool meant focused but not pushy. This man was cool.
When I really, really like a set of images I take the time to capture the images for later meditation. I did that with these.

This article by Ms. Correal, and the photos by Mr. Cobo are of current activity and don't unearth anything about the Carrera Septima or Bogota' and its past. The corner where most shots were taken is the intersection of the Carrera Septima and the Avenida Jimenez. The Central Bank is El Banco de la Republica. The building where El Tiempo used to be was designed by an Italian architect, Bruno Violi. Opposite El Banco de La Republica is La Iglesia de San Francisco, and below that was the Gobernacion de Cundinamarca with a statue of Gonzalo Jimenez de Quesada, the city founder. Going North on the Carrera Septima, just past El Banco de La Republica is El Parque de Santander. Beyond that is the Avianca tower which in years past housed the main post office. A few blocks South of Carrera Septima and Avenida Jimenez is La Plaza de Bolivar, Bogota's main square where the Catedral Primada and the Congress building are...

You touch closely on what if taken too far can be the danger with what is currently called "identity politics", which is subjectivity take too far in that it isolates us from one another--by focusing solely on the idiosyncratic subjective experiences and contingent factors of various groups, whether ethnic, gender or class based-- and while there's definite merit to a lot of the argumentso of inequality and lack of opportunity faced by these groups in the long run the emphasis on subjectiveness used inter arguments is divisive--

Right, George Blackford. It's simple math: if money is drained out of the demand system by people who don't spend (i.e., billionaires and sub-billionaires), it won't be spent on demand and demand will be reduced. If the people who aren't getting that money already had enough and wouldn't be spending it anyway, there would be no reduction in demand. By looking at the world, or just the U.S., as it is, any person can see that people who are losing money to the drainage are losing money they would mostly spend.

It follows that we have to take back our money from the (sub)billionaires. If we elect real people instead of greed robots, we can make that happen. Aye, there's the rub!

Phallocentric? Well there's my new word for the day.
Now if I could just figure out some place I could use it. Wait I know. I go to the front desk at the Getty Center and ask for directions to the Phallocentric exhibit.
Must you bombard us with ads next to these great images? And why can't we view them widescreen? This truly detracts from some great art, NYT.

We need to take a hard look at the money held in and "investments" controlled from tax havens. Nearly all of this $100 trillion is from corrupt despots (and politicians), organized criminals and tax evaders, Seize it all! Eliminate government debts and put this money to work.

People hiding money through tax havens NEVER make real investments, preferring instead to speculate, especially in real estate through dummy companies.

Years ago this was a party trick my then spouse enjoyed playing. We had a small party of even fewer than 23 and a guest was particularly adamant the odds had to be much greater. He turned out to have the same birthday as my spouse. It was great fun.

An outstanding article like this, which lays out what happened very clearly, makes if VERY EASY to think that the correct path was obvious at the time, and that Clinton's choices are simply born of ignorance, stupidity, hubris, etc. instead of doing the best she could while beset by intractable obstacles on every side (including from her boss). If you want hubris and stupidity, look to GWB and his gang. This article shows that, in his wake, the US can't really act effectively at all.

This intervention was bound to bring about the current chaos. Mr. Clinton was caught between the British, French and those who wee doubtful of it possibilities.

The problem as we have seen several times is the actions of other Islamic governments like Qatar. These governments have a history of saying one thing and doing another, then denying it. they are duplicitous and have an agenda that does not promote political stability in the region.

So the issue to start with was, let Qaddafi kill several thousand civilians, non combatants, or intervene and stop the slaughter of innocents? There was no right answer. Clinton did what she believed to be morally right, and if she had not, she would be getting the dame criticism anyway. Qaddafi had murdered Americans, among others, then began cooperating to save his own skin. He would have continued to do as he had been doing anyway.

Worse yet Libya had no formal government tradition, and there was no way to establish one. So each little faction wants to establish their own power center.

It was a no win situation, I think she did what she thought was the right thing to do. All the critics have 20-20 hindsight, but we do not know what they would have don in the same position. It is easy to criticize when you do not have to make the decision.
